p: Because (1) perceived infection risk tracks HIV prevalence ( Fig. 5b,c) and (2) the per capita rates of unprotected sex are driven by changes in the numbers of HIV+ individuals in the age cohorts rather than behavioral changes stemming from altered utility functions per se, the negative feedbacks stimulated by prophylactic vaccination are limited. Although vaccine-protected individuals practice more US than without the vaccine, this does not translate into higher HIV prevalence. And, because vaccinated individuals are always HIVâˆ’, the direct impact on the other actor is minimal.
